Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: I sat at my desk, the optional reading from my mentor open on one tab, and my phone buzzing with notifications on the other. My mentor had suggested I read this article to deepen my understanding, and even though the deadline was weeks away, I knew she’d be pleased if I finished it early. I wanted to show her I was committed, that I valued her guidance. But my activist group’s latest post was exploding online—hundreds of people were commenting, asking questions, and sharing their own stories. If I jumped in now, I could clarify misconceptions and provide resources, maybe even turn this moment into real momentum for our cause. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind about the importance of thorough preparation, but the activist in me felt the urgency of the moment slipping away. I stared at the screen, torn between the quiet responsibility of being a good mentee and the electric pull of making a difference right now. My heart raced as I weighed which expectation mattered more in this moment, feeling the pressure of both roles pressing in on me.
